properties.media:imagetext:
November 14, 1949
My dear Debby,
I was so delighted to receive your letter from
Paris, and I can't think of anything lovelier than
what
you are doing. It sounds ideal
to me.
I think
that
I have always
been a traveler at heart.
I was sorry
that Harold didn't come out to the Far
East
in September with the group that made the trip
on the Stratocruiser.
I am always glad to see Bondie,
of course, but it wasn't until the group walked in
for the luncheon that day that I realized that Harold
had not come but Bondie had come in his place.
You spoke of Elma Stevenot -- I haven't heard from
her now in nearly a year.
Each Christmas
I get a
little note from her.
I had heard that one of the girls
had had an unhappy marriage
and at the time Elma
wrote me about it and how distressed she was.
Evidently
the other girl though has worked her life out better.
Like you I admire Elma very much, and we were
certainly
devoted to Joe.
He got so much out of life and
gave
50 mentha
and I will never forget how shocked
I was at
I had talked to him the day that he flew
from Australia.
He dropped in to see me.
As you know,
we had Slim out here nearly a year ago.
I gathered
from what he said that his mother must be really ter-
ribly ill.
He said she still lived in the same house
in Detroit and that her brother was still living,
which is very fortunate.
I know you miss your grandchildren, but it is
nice
that you can still have one member
of the family
with you - your youngest.
I hope in every way all
your happy plans for this winter work out, and I do
hope
that some
day
our paths may cross again as it
would be so wonderful to see you and talk with you.
Love to you and yours,
Devotedly,
millsfield:images_texts:
November 14, 1949
My dear Debby,
I was so delighted to receive your letter from
Paris, and I can't think of anything lovelier than
what
you are doing. It sounds ideal
to me.

I have always

50 mentha
and I will never forget how shocked
I was at
I had talked to him the day that he flew
from Australia.
He dropped in to see me.
As you know,

from what he said that his mother must be really ter-
ribly ill.

of the family

that some
day
our paths may cross again as it
would be so wonderful to see you and talk with you.
Love to you and yours,
Devotedly,

Mrs. Douglas MacArthur
A. P.O. 500 - c/o Postmaster
San Francisco, California
2 B
Mrs. Harold Bixby
Hotel Roblin
Rue Cheveau Lagarde
Paris 9, France
UNITED
STATES

VIA AIR MAIL
